title: TRU Day of Giving
description: TRU Day of Giving is your chance to invest in education, training, research and scholarship that makes a difference in the lives of students. Stay tuned for more on featured funds, challenges and on-campus activities.
location: This Event is at any locations on campus

title: Last day of withdrawa semester course with no academic penalty
description: Starting Tuesday, Jan. 16, join Multi-Faith Chaplain Venerable Ani Gawa Khandro in the new Inclusion and Wellness Activity room in Old Main room 1522 every Tuesday from 1 – 2:30 p.m. for free Dharma talks and guided meditation. Everyone is welcome!

title: Actors Workshop Theatre-Rhinoceros
description:
The Actors Workshop Theatre is hosting Rhinoceros by Eugene Ionesco on Thursday, Feb. 29, Saturday, Mar. 2 and Thursday, Mar. 7 to Saturday, Mar. 9.
When a rhinoceros charges across the town square one Sunday afternoon, Berenger thinks nothing of it.
Soon, rhinoceroses are popping up everywhere and Berenger’s whole world is under threat.
What will it take for him to stand up to the increasing menace of rhinocerization?
Tickets are $20 and can be purchased at tru.ca/awt

title: TRU BLSA Trivia Night
description:
For our last event during Black History Month, TRU BLSA is hosting a trivia night at Fox’n Hounds Pub, on Sunday Mar. 3 at 5:15 p.m.
Each table can have a maximum of six people and please RSVP using the link here.
The winning team gets bragging rights and prizes!

title: Indigenous Awareness Week
description:
TRU wants solar tables around campus to promote renewable energy use, encourage student learning, and have more outdoor places to study and socialize that are protected from the weather.
Students can enter the competition individually or as part of a team.
Only one table will be chosen as the winning submission.
Winners receive a $650 prize and their table will be constructed and displayed on campus.
Competition guidelines can be found on the website here.
All submissions should be sent to the Sustainability Office at sustain@tru.ca on or before Monday, Mar. 4.

title: TRU Repair Café
description:
Do you have small household items or clothing and textiles that need to be repaired or altered?
Don’t throw them away; bring them to the Repair Café!
The Repair Café is a free event organized by the TRU Sustainability Office in partnership with Repair Café Kamloops and TRU Makerspace.
It will take place on Tuesday, Mar. 5 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. at Makerspace which is located on the first floor in the Brown Family House of Learning.
The event is open to all, and no registration is needed.
Items tht will be accepted at the TRU event include:
• Clothing and textiles that need typical repairs
• Small household electronic appliances and electrical items
• Wood furniture that needs simple repairs
• Bicycles
Items that will not be accepted include:
• Gas or other fuel powered devices
• Computers or cell phones
• Anything that needs two or more people to carry
For more information, visit tru.ca/repaircafe or contact the TRU Sustainability Office at sustain@tru.ca.

Everyone is welcome!

title: On-Campus bible study
description:
Connect with your spirituality this semester with the Multi-Faith Chaplaincy!
Join TRU Chaplain Narayan Mitra in Old Main room 1522 every Wednesday this semester from 11 a.m. – 12 p.m.

title: Research ethics lunch series
description:
Speakers: Dr. Jennifer Shaw (Anthropology/Sociology), Dr. Rebecca Sanford (Social Work)
All faculty, staff and students engaged in research are welcome!
Are you considering working with children or youths in your research?
Come and chat with REB members about research ethics with young people in terms of capacity to consent, assent versus consent, crafting child-friendly consent forms and the opportunities and challenges of requiring parental or guardian consent.
Ways to connect:
We are here to support your research and answer questions.
Please email us at TRU-REB@tru.ca.
Online drop-in times:
Jan. 17 from 2-3 p.m.
Feb. 7 from 2-3 p.m.
Mar. 20 from 2-3 p.m.
Find us at bit.ly/TRUrebchat

title: On-Campus bible study
description:

title: Power Engineering - info session
description:
Become a leader in the field of power engineering!
We offer the Power Engineering Technology Diploma.
As a power engineer, you’ll maintain and operate heating and power plants, refrigeration systems and equipment like pumps, compressors, steam turbines, electrical generators and water treatment systems. Upon completion of the two-year diploma, you will become a certified 3rd class power engineer. Graduates work in commercial facilities including hospitals, schools, mills, and power generation stations to name a few.
At this information session, we will provide you with an overview of the program, offer valuable insights into career opportunities and walk through the admission process.
Date:  Wednesday, March 6
Location: Virtual
Time: 6 – 7 p.m. (PT)
Host: Byron Poppleton, Assistant Teaching Professor
Register here 
Get in touch
Interested in exploring the program now?
Check out the program here.

title: Art Lecture Series - Dr. Benjamin Woodford
description:
Join the art lecture series!
Dr. Benjamin Woodford, assistant professor of English, will be lecturing on Liberty and Government: John Milton’s Career as a Civil Servant and his Policies for Freedom.
All are welcome and no registration is required.
When: Friday, Mar. 8 from noon – 1 p.m.
Where: Arts and Education building in room 208

title: Week of Idays(International Days)
description:
Join us for a two-day conference and launch of the Volume 8 Knowledge Makers journal in partnership with the Food and Agriculture Org of the United Nations.
This partnership aims to empower Indigenous women through research and knowledge creation, focusing on food sovereignty and climate resilience.
We will proudly host six global Indigenous Knowledge Makers at TRU’s campus, celebrating their contributions to food sovereignty and climate resilience.
The event includes the launch of a collaborative edition of their work, as well as opportunities for knowledge-sharing, networking, and community festivities.
When: Monday, Mar. 11 – Tuesday, Mar. 12, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Where: CAC

title: Metis Nation BC - My TRU Experience
description:
Ready to unlock your future?
Join us for an electrifying journey at the MYTRU Experience, taking place from Tuesday, Mar. 12 to Thursday, Mar. 14, 2024, hosted by TRU and Métis Nation BC (Ministry of Youth).
Dive into an immersive cultural learning alongside vibrant Métis youth.
Experience hands-on cultural activities while learning from Indigenous community leaders and elders.
Connect deeply with your roots through engaging activities like the drum group, jigging, sashing ceremonies and more.
Seeking your career path?
Explore, discover and engage with various departments – from business to law, veterinary sciences to trades and technology, healthcare to horticulture and beyond.
Take exclusive campus tours, mingle with faculty and current students and get your questions answered.
Register here

title: Bachelor of Engineering in Software Engineering - info session
description:
Become a leader in the exciting field of software engineering!
We offer the Bachelor of Engineering in Software Engineering program.
In just four years, prepare for an exciting career as a software engineer or software designer. Learn how, where and why software will be used to meet the needs of the end user, technical information to design, develop and test software and develop and manage database systems to name a few.
At this information session, we will provide you with a program overview as well as insights into career opportunities upon graduation.

title: Respiratory therapy - mandatory info session
description:
In the process of applying to the Respiratory Therapy program?
Join us on Tuesday, Mar. 12, 2024 from 6 – 7:30 p.m. to learn about the application process, program options, salaries and job opportunities.
Attendance at this info session or upcoming sessions is a requirement for admission.
These sessions provide insight into the profession and the program and may answer any outstanding questions.
Please email resp@tru.ca for an online link to the date you have chosen.
All virtual sessions are on Zoom and are in Pacific Time (PT).

title: Environmental sciencse seminar
description:

Seminar title: Who cares about lynx? Impacts of wildfire on boreal forests and Canada lynx in Washington, US

title: Distinguished Lecture in Human Right and Social Justic
description:
In the 2010 issue of Forbes Magazine, Dr. Shiva was identified as being one of seven of “the world’s most powerful feminists” working on social justice issues around the globe.
Here is a brief video to serve as a primer on her extensive work and impact as both scientist and activist.
Vandana Shiva holds a PhD in quantum theory from the University of Western Ontario.
She is the founder and main force behind the Research Foundation for Science, Technology and Ecology (RFSTE) and Navdanya, a national movement to protect the diversity and integrity of living resources.
In 1993, she was awarded the highly prestigious Right Livelihood Award, seen by many as the alternative Noble Peace Prize.
location: Campus Activity Centre TRU Grand Hall

title: Arts Lecture Series - Dr.Nicolas Hrynyk
description:
Join the art lecture series!
Dr. Nicholas Hrynyk, assistant professor of history, will be lecturing on Stunning Gowns, Fine Singing, Great Impersonations: Class, Race, and Gender in the 1920s and 30s Female Impersonation Scene of Windsor-Detroit.
All are welcome and no registration is required.

title: bachelor of Communication and Digital Journalism - info session
description:
Become a leader in this exciting field!
We offer the Bachelor of Communication and Digital Journalism program.
Embrace studies in public and strategic communication, media relations, media and technology, multimedia storytelling, digital journalism, visual communication and digital design. With this degree, you will be ready to navigate flexible opportunities as a digital journalist, a public relations specialist, a media analyst or a content producer.
At this information session, we will provide you with an overview of the program, offer valuable insights into career opportunities and walk through the admission process.

title: Human servic Work - info session
description:
Pursue a fulfilling, rewarding career!
We offer the Human Service Diploma and Education Assistant and Community Support (EACS) Certificate.
Prepare for a meaningful career. Upon graduation of the Human Service Diploma, you can work with government or non-profit agencies to support individuals and families with diverse social needs. The EACS certificate prepares you to support and serve children, youth or adults through teaching important educational, social, vocational, recreational and personal life skills.
At this information session, we will provide you with an overview of the programs, insights into career opportunities and walk through the admission process.

title: Free robotic Workshop
description:
Women in Engineering is hosting a free rootics workshop on  for high school students!
Girls in grades eleven and twelve are invited to register for our workshop, where they will receive hands-on experience creating a working robot while learning robotics skills.
Participants will:
Tour the Makerspace
Explore VR equipment
Make buttons and stickers
Test podcasting skills
Hear from keynote speaker Lorelei Guidos
Enjoy lunch
Have fun!
